abstract: Study published in journal Proceedings of the Royal Society B Biological Sciences finds Rattus norvegicus, also known as brown rat, originated in wilds of northern China or Mongolia before attaching themselves to human habitations and colonizing throughout world; spreading of rat, common in New York City, took place mainly over past three centuries.

keywords.value: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)
keywords.name: organizations

lead_paragraph: Brown rats were confined to Asia until 300 years ago, a DNA study found. Then European colonizers helped them take over the world.
snippet: Brown rats were confined to Asia until 300 years ago, a DNA study found. Then European colonizers helped them take over the world....

headline.main: How the Brown Rat Conquered New York City (and Every Other One, Too)
headline.print_headline: How the Mean, Mysterious Brown Rat Took Over Cities
